fields.description: It would be nice to be able to clone/copy tasks between jobs and other plans the same way we can clone plans and jobs.
fields.summary: Would like ability to clone/copy tasks to other jobs/plans

fields.description: Sure would be nice to be able to copy a task from another job/plan/stage  while editing a bamboo job. We have separate builds for environments, and every time I make a change to one, I need to make the same change in five other plans. The auto complete is helpful but it would be really nice to be able to do a copy function quickly.  Frequently when creating new builds I find that I need to add a new stage to segregate critical functions from less critical ones (supplemental reports are not as critical as the compiles for example). So moving a task from one stage to another would also be very useful.
fields.summary: Copy task/job from one job/plan/stage to another during configuration.

fields.description:
It is currently not possible to have the same release for two different environments under a deployment project that is triggered by a plan, even if breaking the environments into two separate deployment projects, when the same plan triggers them, they still get different release numbers despite all the settings to make them have the same release.

Please make it possible to have the same release number for different environments in a deployment project.
fields.summary: The ability to create the same release in all environments with each deployment

This issue is very hard to be replicated, but it has been confirmed as a bug.

h4. Workaround
* Stop Bamboo
* Navigate to WEB-INF/lib
* Backup {{atlassian-bamboo-api-5.0.1.jar}} and {{atlassian-bamboo-core-5.0.1.jar}}
* Remove {{atlassian-bamboo-api-5.0.1.jar}} and {{atlassian-bamboo-core-5.0.1.jar}}
* Copy [^atlassian-bamboo-api-5.0-SNAPSHOT.jar] and [^atlassian-bamboo-core-5.0-SNAPSHOT.jar] files into WEB-INF/lib
* Start Bamboo

fields.description:
We are using bamboo for building our iOS app for an enterprise deployment.  Generally it works great; and we have the "perform a clean build" checkmark checked as part of our plan.

However, there is a coredata persistentStore file that is not being removed from the cache --- NOTE: this is almost certainly a limitation of the xcode clean process because similar problems exists using xcode unless the developer does a "simulator reset" or "deletes the app from the device" --- i.e. CoreData persistenStore files are not deleted as part of the standard xcode "clean this build".

This creates a giant problem for us because we are getting stale persistentStore files in all of our builds and cannot seem to find a way to reset the cache and generate a clean build.  I've verified that the up-to-date/correct file is in the git repot and verified that the old/out-of-date file is being included in our apps (downloaded/unzipped the .ipa file).

I'm looking for a short-term/immediate solution as well as a longer term solution --- i.e. how can I immediately destroy the build cache and force a truly from-scratch clean build; and how can we prevent this from happening in the future via a checkbox etc.?

For us, this is currently a pretty major blocking bug because we cannot ship a new build to our enterprise users.
fields.summary: xcode cache not being properly destroyed

fields.description:
We just added an artifact download task to a build.  We have a build plan that generates a shared artifact.  Another build plan wants to download that artifact.  The artifact download seems to fail when the downloading build is kicked off as a child build of another plan. 

When the artifact download works, we see this in the log:
{code}
simple	21-Aug-2013 01:20:03	Starting task 'Download Backup Client' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	21-Aug-2013 01:20:03	Preparing to download plan result CAV-BKUPRELEASE-15 artifact: Shared artifact: [Stash Backup-Restore Client Release], pattern: [stash-backup-distribution-*.zip] anchored at: [target/checkout/distribution/target]
simple	21-Aug-2013 01:20:05	Artifact [Stash Backup-Restore Client Release] downloaded successfully in 2s
simple	21-Aug-2013 01:20:05	Finished task 'Download Backup Client'
{code}

When the artifact download doesn't work, we see this:
{code}
simple	21-Aug-2013 01:44:34	Starting task 'Download Backup Client' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'

The page was open whilst I rebuilt a bad build in another tab.  I'm guessing only the build number updated to green, not the icon.

fields.description:
I have a Bamboo project that requires *Plan Variables* for both build and deployment stages.

h4. DURING THE BUILD STAGE:

Both *Automated* and *Manual* builds are able to access and resolve my *Plan Variables* for any tasks created under the plan. 
{code}
This is an example of a Plan Variable:
-D:build.version=${bamboo.PWSIMS_VERSION} 
{code}

*NOTE:* I am using continuous integration so *Automated* builds are generated every time I check in a change to source control using GIT.

h4. DURING THE DEPLOYMENT STAGE:

Only Releases created from *Manual* builds are able to access and resolve my *Plan Variables* (ie {{bamboo.PWSIMS_VERSION}}) for any tasks created under the deployment definition.

Any Releases created from an *Automated* build end up loosing all *Plan Variables*, thus causing the Deployment project to fail.

h4. PLEASE NOTE

I am not the only user who has experienced this:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Variables+for+deployment+environments?focusedCommentId=389775441#comment-389775441
fields.summary: Automated Builds: Plan variables disappearing in Deployment Tab
Bamboo deployment dashboard slow when displaying many deployment projects

fields.description: One of the use cases of this REST API service can be sending email notifications from Script tasks based on a certain script condition.
fields.summary: Add REST API service to send email notifications from Bamboo

fields.description:
Current versions of Bamboo are using this dialect:
{code:xml}
<property name="hibernate.dialect">com.atlassian.hibernate.dialect.MySQL5Dialect</property>
{code}

Older versions used to use MySQLDialect (without the 5), and this property is not updated by any of the Bamboo upgrade tasks.  This causes columns that should be created with {{varchar(4000)}} to instead be created as {{text}}.  It can lead to errors in the logs while adding indices:
[Unsuccessful: create index Error in Logs Using MySQL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Unsuccessful%3A+create+index+Error+in+Logs+Using+MySQL]

We should have an upgrade task update the dialect automatically and notify that the change requires a restart.
fields.summary: Bamboo instances upgraded from old versions still using MySQLDialect

fields.description: Bamboo automatically links all the related JIRA issues and build plans to the deployment project. If there is a shared repository in Bamboo that many plans use, this can generate a lot of noise in the "Commits tested by" section of deployment releases. Add a feature to manage what gets linked to the deployment project.
fields.summary: Add a feature to manage what gets linked to a deployment project if there is a shared repository used in build plans

fields.description:
The artifact configuration for jobs should have an additional configuration option similar to the share/unshare link that defines whether the artifact will be "required" or "optional".  A required artifact is expected to be created by the job, and if not created it is considered that the entire job has failed.
An optional artifact is a by-product the job will collect at the end of its run, but it may sometimes not be created and in such cases it is not considered as a failure.

This proposal is to mitigate the current behavior where artifacts not created or copied from remote agent to build server has no effect on the build status unless if it is a subscribed artifact.
fields.summary: Shared artifacts should be configurable to optionally fail the build or not

A similiar message is reported by Mac remote agents.

Workaround: Disabling the Advanced Repository Option: "Enable Repository Caching on Remote Agents" for each repository clears the error.

Renabling remote agent caching after a succesful build works for a while, but eventually fails again. Deleting all caches via the bamboo administration page, triggers the errors again, unless caching is disabled.

We are using ssh to access our repositories. We have setup the user accounts running the remote agents and the bamboo server to use the ssh settings in the .ssh folder. Authentication for all repositories are set to none. In each case of failure, we can easily login as the user running the agent or the bamboo server and retrieve the git repository on the command line.

Everything worked without issue before the upgrade from 5.0rc1 to 5.0.1.

fields.description:
Currently source code repositories can be set up for global access or specific to a plan. Some of our users would benefit a lot from the concept of project specific repositories.

They currently have many plans checking out the same code and in the event of handover between users or a password change (when not using keys), they have to go through all their plans and update the authentication.
fields.summary: Project specific repositories

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
If there's a variable of the URL of the subversion or git repository in Bamboo plan, and when you run customised and override the variable wrongly, the plan will be disabled after the build is unabled to run. This could cause issues if the developers don't have the permission to enable the plan, and it might cause bottleneck in the process. This issue could also be replicated if you put wrong url in the Source repository in Plan configuration.

(!) This happens if the git branch name is wrong as well.

*Steps to replicate*
# Navigate to _Configure Plan_
# On the Source repository, choose Subversion or Git and put wrong URL
# Add _Source Code Checkout_ task
# Run the build
# Notice the build won't be able to run and the plan is disabled

*Another step to replicate*
# Navigate to _Configure Plan_
# On the Source repository, choose Subversion or Git and put URL and Bamboo variable at the end, make sure the default value is valid URL. For example.
{noformat}
http://svnserver/Repo/svn/${bamboo.svnbranchname}
{noformat}
# _Run Customised_ the plan and override the variable with wrong value
# Notice the build won't be able to run and the plan is disabled
fields.summary: Plan is disabled if the URL of Subversion/Git is wrong

fields.description:
When assigning agents to an environment, agents that are not able to complete all the tasks required are still listed.  [Our documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Agents+for+deployment+environments] states that "Only agents applicable to the deployment environment will be available for selection," which is not true.

In my test instance, I [removed the Ant Capability^agent.png] from one of my Remote Agents, and [added a task for Ant to my environment^antneeded.png].  However, the agent it is still listed as a "capable server" when looking at either the [tasks view^tasksview.png] for my deployment environment, or when setting a [dedicated agent^dedicated.png] for the environment.

This is problematic because Bamboo will chose a capable agent if you do not set a dedicated agent.  This is from the "Edit agents" page:
bq. If you do not assign an agent to this deployment, one will be chosen at run time according to standard requirement/capability mappings.

If an agent cannot perform all of the tasks because it lacks a capability, it should not be listed.  Moreover, Bamboo will still attempt to use this server, and if it does, the deployment *will* fail needlessly.
fields.summary: Agents not capable of running deployment tasks still show as available agents

fields.summary: Make possible to clone a user account.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up global build expiry to have the "Expiry period" of 1 days (Please check the attached screenshot for additional details.)
2. Run selected plans making sure that the results will be expired when the build expiry runs. (Example: If the build expiry runs at 12 pm every day, do not run these builds after 11:30 am today and check the result 12:30 pm tomorrow).
3. When the expiry runs, the plans shows up in the UI as "Never Built".
4. {color:blue}When the build fails and I use the "Assign Responsibility" feature, even after expiry runs and the plan shows up as "Never Built", I still see these plans under My Bamboo/My Broken Plans. Should these be removed at some point from under this tab if the result of the failed builds are deleted?{color}. If there are results other than the failed results that are older than one day, the build is not showing up as "Never Built" any more but the plan still shows up under My Bamboo/My Broken Plans even after failed build results are removed. If I re-run these plans, then the data from under My Broken Plans is removed (NeverBuilt_5.PNG).

Please check the attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Plan shows up as "Never Built" after build expiry runs

fields.description:
I have some unit tests (622 of them) and 620 passed, two failed. We're using the CPPUnit parser.

Bamboo clearly noticed that the tests failed, since in the build log:

15-Aug-2013 20:34:12	Starting task 'Collect unit tests' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.cppunit.bamboo-cppunit-plugin:test'
15-Aug-2013 20:34:12	Parsing test results...
15-Aug-2013 20:34:12	Failing task since 2 failing test cases were found.
15-Aug-2013 20:34:12	Finished task 'Collect unit tests'

however when I look at the "Tests" page I see "The following 620 tests have passed:" and when I click on "Failed Tests" I see "There were no failed tests in this build."

From what I can see, the parser is working correctly, but the "tests" view isn't showing the failed tests.

It clearly knows those tests happened because it says "622 tests in total"

Edit the description note in the plan dependency tab

fields.description:
After project key rename information about past builds for issue/project performed for old issue key/project key is not visible. It seems JIRA Bamboo plugin cannot handle project key renames.

More information:
This problem relates to issue keys parsed from commit messages and stored in Bamboo against build results. We have no information about Jira notifying connected applications about project key rename, thus Bamboo doesn't have a chance to act upon this.
fields.summary: JBAM - Jira Bamboo plugin does not handle project key rename in JIRA

fields.description:
Currently artifacts linked to deployments are stored in the directory 'globalStorage' in the artifacts directory of the bamboo server.

These artifacts never expire, and so as time goes on more and more disk space is used up. In the month and a half of EBAC using deployments, we've already accumulated 25GB of deployment artifacts, and that's set to increase. It's contributing to https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/BUILDENG-3867

I'd imagine that OnDemand wouldn't be too happy with ever increase disk usage either.
fields.summary: Allow deployment artifacts to be expired

fields.description: The maven import and the dependency processor uses the maven embedder not the system binary and as such the import uses user defined. In the case of a dependency processor, users have the option to specify alternative paths in case the files are located somewhere centrally. It will be great to expand this feature to maven import as well since both uses the maven embedder.
fields.summary: Set the option to configure alternate path for settings file when importing a maven project

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When creating release and deployment builds it commonly desired to tag the commit that was built.  For example, the Maven release plugin does this automatically.  For projects that don't use Maven we need a way to tag the release code to avoid manual steps.

It is also useful to build from a Git tag.  For example, when you need to redeploy a release artifact from the past that is not present in Bamboo.

h3. Suggested Solution

* Add a build step that will tag the currently checked out commit.
* Add the ability to select Git tags for build steps.
* Make this work in Git repositories hosted in Stash and BitBucket as well.

h3. Workaround 
# Configure Source Code Checkout task in the Build Plan to checkout source.git into a directory for building the code
# Add another Source Code Checkout task in the Build Plan at the bottom of the task to checkout deploy.git into another directory
# With this deploy.git, check what is the latest changeset/revision (probably “git log -1”) with a Script task to save the changeset/revision into a file
# Create an Artifact for this file in step 3
# In the environment task, use Script task to read this file in step 3 and perform Git checkout with it in the same Script task

With this workaround, the deployment in other environment or rollback will be able to perform Git checkout on the same changeset/revision depending on the Artifact.

(!) NOTE: For this approach you will need to setup a private key on remote agent(s) so the agent will have permission to access the repository directly. This is because the credentials stored in the Bamboo server aren't available to the script task as it is executed by the 'bamboouser' on the remote agent.
fields.summary: Ability to checkout and create tags in a Git repository

{noformat}
= 2 minutes to remove 19 entries?

Some facts:
* The plan the bean is currently working on is idle for about 5 months
* The current expiry settings are 1 week and 3 builds
* We run out of disc space before the BuildExpiryBean can catch up
* Thus, all files on disc have been purged manually by a find & delete script because they were older than 90 days 
* So removing an artifact is just the database operation

I understand it runs in the background, probably with low priority. Still: why does it take so long to remove the builds? 

According to the code, the BuildExpiryBean iterates through the plans sorted by name. This plan (BREAKIT) is probably the first one. But at that rate I doubt it will catch up and actually delete expired data from current plans. At least not at the rate new content is created. This forces us to clear the files directly on disc to avoid running out of disc space.

Can I kindly ask to improve the performance on this, please? Thanks
fields.summary: BuildExpiryBean (or one of its collaborators) is very slow

fields.description:
My company currently has 150+ code repositories (common libraries, plugins, front-ends, tools, etc), each of which is represented by a Plan in Bamboo, and each of these Plans execute the exact same build pipeline sequence of Stages/Jobs/Tasks via the use of paramaterised tasks. The only field that differs from Plan to Plan is the Source repository that Plan is associated with.

The issue is that if for example I wanted to add a common "Generate Reports" job for each plan, I have to manually add this Job and it's tasks to all 150+ plans - which is quite time consuming and monotonous, not to mention prone to introducing inconsistencies between plans over time.

A way to greatly reduce the amount of time required to update a large number of plans with the exact same Stages/Jobs/Tasks pipeline would be a huge help. 

Two potential solutions are:

1) Implement some form of "Plan template" that a plan could inherit from. Then any subsequent changes to the template would propagate through all plans associated with it.

TeamCity CI Server has an implementation along these lines: http://confluence.jetbrains.com/display/TCD8/Build+Configuration+Template

2) Enhance the current "Plans -> Bulk Action" functionality to allow for the adding/removing of Stages/Jobs to multiple plans at a time.

fields.description:
When a build is triggered by a Bitbucket push, the build plan reason text says "Manual build by <bitbucket user>" instead of what it usually does under Fisheye/Subversion, where it either reads "Changes by <committer>" or "Changes by X people".

It would be nice if the trigger from Bitbucket could be changed to something other than the "manual build" verbiage, as it is nice for us to be able to tell at a quick glance that a build was triggered by a source code commit. It is also somewhat confusing since the build wasn't really a manual run at all, it was triggered by Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Display "changes by" build reason text in Bamboo builds when triggered by Bitbucket

fields.description:
For some types of projects, passing artifacts is not appropriate or efficient. Deployment may include all of the source files and not have a true "build" stage. An example would be a python django project. In our case, we use Heroku for deployment as well, and the deploy is a git push action.

Currently, in my build plan, I check out the code and run a bunch of tests. Then, in order to use the deploy plan, I basically have to zip up the entire repository and pass it up as an artifact. Pull it back down during deploy, unzip, and so on.

Additionally, we work on an agency model and we can't make all nominally "shared" deployment repositories available globally due to confidentiality concerns; we cannot allow one internal team access to environment information that's applicable to other client teams. These may be shared among a number of projects, but we still need to set them up as plan repositories for those security reasons. 

Please allow checking out plan repositories during Deployment.
fields.summary: Ability to check out plan repository in deployment plan

fields.description:
When using the Deployment task, Source Code Checkout it is a requirement for us to toggle when we want latest code or the code that was linked to the specific build where the artifact is coming from.

Scenario:

We want to deploy build 10 but at the moment we are at build 30 and the scripts for making deployment has changed between 10 and 30. If we make a deployment based on 10 but the scripts from 30 then the deployment will most likely fail.
fields.summary: Add possibility to specify what revision of code to checkout

fields.description:
Currently deployment plans are coupled to build plans, and environments are contained in deployment plans.
This doesn't allow sharing of environments between build/deployment plans. For example some QA setup may be used by two different projects.

It would be better if Bamboo would allow storing information about an environment and its "targets" (could be a server, CDN, WEBDAV, ...). Every target will have steps which take an input artifact and make sure it is deployed on that target.
A deployment plan would then be a mapping between artifacts and a deployment environment, allowing sharing of environments.
fields.summary: Globally defined deployment environments

fields.description:
A user wants to test his include regular expression for his repository without triggering a build. The files he wants to include as his repo trigger are shared across a few projects and are sensitive. He doesn't want to edit them in order to check his Bamboo plan will trigger.

If there was a 'test regex' button next to the File Pattern item in the repository template that reported how the regex currently matched it would be very useful.
fields.summary: Testing repository regular expressions is hard.

fields.description:
This relates to the [variable injection plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo-variable-inject-task/].

Variables dynamically added by that plugin are available to the originating plan, however they are not available to any deployment environments associated with the plan. In particular it is not possible to use this plugin to use variables in the release version (e.g. release-$\{bamboo.inject.version\})
fields.summary: Dynamically defined variables not propagated to deployment environment

fields.description:
Bamboo sets a local proxy for Git connections. When a test plan is configured to use a username and password it appears that these are not only saved in plaintext, but are passed as plaintext to the Git proxy and also saved in the log files.

At the least, these passwords should never be saved to log files.
fields.summary: Bamboo passes user credentials in plaintext to Git
Deployment logs fail if null log entry.

fields.description: You can't clone from a shallow clone, which causes the build to fail.
fields.summary: git caches on agents can't be shallow clones
Customise Run Plan fails to load variables

fields.description: Key Edit Box Length should be larger, so that you can see more of what you are entering while you type it in.  There is a lot of space on the right of the edit box that can be used since this value is typically longer than the Key.

fields.description: In deployment feature that is introduced in Bamboo 5.0, there are only 3 triggers, which is documented on [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Triggers+for+deployment+environments]. It would be better if there's an additional trigger which deploys the release upon approval on that particular release in the deployment, as some of users require this automation process in their deployment.
fields.summary: Add trigger in deployment upon approving Release

fields.description:
*Problem:*

The 'aggregate' view of the Clover plugin contains $\{buildKey} in the URL. It is fine for the standalone Bamboo installation:

!bamboo_standalone.png!

but fails on OnDemand (I guess there are some security restrictions applied):

!bamboo_ondemand.png!


*Steps to reproduce:*

Enable Clover in the project. Run build with Clover to generate HTML/XML reports. Open the Plan Summary page, click on the Clover tab. 

*Suggested fix:*

Change the *<web-item key="...">* so that it will not contain anything with *$\{...}*


*Workaround for OnDemand:*

Replace the buildKey by the actual project-plan-job identifier, for instance:

https://your.bamboo.server/builds/build/viewCloverSummary.action?buildKey=PROJECT-PLAN-JOB1
fields.summary: Remove the ${buildKey} from Clover plugin URLs

fields.description:
A build may produce many shared artifacts but only a couple are used in the deployment.  It would be good to be able to select specific artifacts that will be available at the project level. 

* All the extra artifacts take up valuable storage space.
* Created versions don't represent a complete source of truth cause there is lots of other crap in them.
fields.summary: Ability to select artifacts used by a deployment at the project level

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# start a build on a plan PL on project PR
# go to the project PR page where the list of plans are shown
# we see that the build icon is the blue spinning one and the build is running
# wait till the build is completed
# expect to see all columns of the plan PL updated to reflect the build-completed status
#* actual: 
#** the "Completed" column was updated properly, but the "Build" column still had the blue spinning icon. It should be updated to reflect the outcome of the build, either red or green.  
#** Staying on the page will see the "Completed" column continues to be updated with relative timestamp, but no changes happen to the build icon.
#** Refreshing the page shows the correct status icon
fields.summary: Status icon not updated on browse project page when build is completed

fields.description:
The default value of 0 for session.validationinterval leads to poor performance. As the documentation says, it means that every single incoming request to the application will need to make at least one request out to Crowd. Currently when using SSO (i.e. the Crowd authenticator) it makes 2 connections to Crowd per request. One to validate the SSO token and one to get the SSO cookie configuration.

We should change the default value in the bundled properties file (and update the documentation) to a non-zero value so it looks up the user from the session until the validation interval is reached.
fields.summary: Change bundled crowd.properties session.validationinterval to 2 to prevent poor performance

fields.description: MS SQL Server 2012 currently is not a [supported platform|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms] (which means that we don't test it). However, when I tried to use it with Bamboo, everything worked just fine. Please add MSSQL Server 2012 as a supported version.
fields.summary: Add MS SQL Server 2012 support for Bamboo

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a plan variable under the variables tab of the plan (Ex.:thisisatest)(Screenshot: DefineTheVariable.PNG)
2. Create a deployment project that gets triggered after the completion of this plan
3. Use the custom plan variables in tasks under both the plan and deployment project tasks
4. If the plan is triggered from the repository(Git in this case), having the "Repository triggers the build when changes are committed" selected, the variable value shows up for the build but not for the deployment
5. If I run the build manually, the variable gets substituted for both the build and the deployment
Please check the attached screenshots. Release-4 is the manual run, Release-5 is triggered by repo.
fields.summary: Plan variable values are not getting substituted for deployments when triggered by repository
